title: Deliveroo raises targets as demand hold up
text:
Deliveroo hiked year-end sales targets after fears of a post-lockdown collapse in food delivery demand proved unfounded. But the company also cautioned that increased investment would hold back on profitability.

Gross transaction value in the second quarter beat expectations at £1.7bn, up 76 per cent year on year. The out-turn was a slight slowdown from the 94 per cent growth reported for the first quarter but still allowed for an increase of annual guidance.

For the full year Deliveroo targeted growth from between 30 and 40 per cent to between 50 and 60 per cent.

However, the full-year gross margin will be in the lower end of the previously communicated range, the company cautioned. It cited an acceleration of discretionary investments and a reversion of the average order value back to pre-Covid levels.

Deliveroo shares closed at a record high of 320p on Wednesday though are still 17 per cent below the 390p issue price on its March flotation.

Briefly

Persimmon said it was accelerating cash returns to shareholders on the back of strong trading. The housebuilder said in a trading update that it performed well during the first half of the year, delivering new home sales completions approaching the levels achieved in the first half of 2019. Shareholders will now receive a single one-off 110p dividend in August rather than two payments in the calendar year as previously planned.

Ladbrokes owner Entain said its full-year earnings will beat expectations. The bookmaker targeted annual ebitda in the range of £850m to £900m after reporting an 11 per cent rise in first-half gaming revenue. Entain also said it was doubling investment in its in-house games studios.

Watches of Switzerland set out a long-term plan to accelerate growth in the UK, US and European markets. The luxury watch retailer's 2026 strategic plan earmarked capital expenditure of between £300m and £340m and up to £200m for acquisitions as management seeks to enter Europe and take a share of the fragmented US market. Full-year results from Watches of Switzerland showed operating profit up 69.5 per cent to £81.9m on revenue up 13.3 per cent to £905.1m.

Great Portland Estates said it had collected 86 per cent of its rent roll for the June quarter. An acceleration in inquiries earlier in the year has translated into healthy leasing activity, particularly for prime Grade A property and flexible offices, the Central London developer said.

Electrocomponents said recent trading has been very strong across all its regions, though higher freight costs remain a problem. The electronics distributor posted like-for-like revenue growth of 37 per cent for the first quarter ended June.

Retailer WHSmith said that based on stronger than hoped trading in North America it anticipates “a small improvement to management's expectations for the current financial year”. At a group level second-quarter revenue was 58 per cent of pre-pandemic levels, it said.

Companies and accountants have attacked sweeping plans to overhaul UK auditing and corporate governance following financial scandals, claiming the changes would stifle businesses' growth and increase costs. The Quoted Companies Alliance, which represents small and medium-sized listed companies, said the cost of “overburdensome regulation” was already shrinking public markets and the reforms risked “worsening the situation”.

The UK government has asked the nation's biggest lenders to help come up with swift solutions to the cladding crisis, which has left as many as 2m people unable to sell their homes in the wake of the 2017 Grenfell Tower fire. Downing Street sought the views of top industry executives on the problem, which has frozen a substantial chunk of the property market and left many leaseholders facing huge costs for fire safety measures.

Beyond the Square Mile

Former US president Donald Trump said he would lead class actions against Facebook, YouTube and Twitter as well as their chief executives Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey and Sundar Pichai in lawsuits alleging “unlawful censorship” of Americans.

US antitrust enforcers have mounted their first challenge to a mobile app store, accusing Google of overcharging developers who sell through the Play store that is built into its Android operating system.

The $50bn Gates Foundation has announced a plan that would allow Melinda French Gates to resign as co-chair of the charity and receive “personal resources” from her estranged husband for her own philanthropic effort if she or Bill Gates decided they could no longer work together.
